concerned with what do you want at the end rather than how precisely do I achieve it the most common example of a
declarative programming environment is SQL if you look at an SQL statement do
you really care what the order of execution of that statement is no and it is not the audio United in either the
select is typically one of the very last things actually executed similarly with functional programming we're not
interested in the order of execution we're just interested in more directly describing what we want at the end

would then wait a week or so gather all the Punch Cards up and then feed them into the computer one at a time take the

from and this was one of the other things that annoyed older John Candy quite a lot he wanted it to be possible
for just anybody to be able to play on the computers and have a go at using them so he teamed it with another
gentleman you see it without Sir Thomas Kurtz and they came up with two things
which were revolutionary in their day or at least rather implemented uh one was time sharing
so the idea was you would still have one computer on campus and it would still be that giant old Mainframe but then you
would have terminals dotted around the campus which were connected to the Mainframe and it would constantly shift
its attention between them and it would give you the appearance that you were interacting with an individual
um terminal on the computer but in fact you weren't it was just flicking between them and this was one method by which
you could actually have direct access to the computer and work on it live as it were
and the other was that he wanted a programming language which was a bit more approachable than what they had in
